text: is it quite emotional being back here in
Pakistan so usually don't get emotional
but yesterday when I gave my first talk
after my visit to Pakistan I just could
not stop my tears and it it is emotional
each and everything I see I I it is it
is valuable to me even just this warm
air i I'll you it and I'm enjoying it
and I am just so happy to be home and to
put my feet on this land again but even
just like meeting family members and
friends and and and just hugging them
and and seeing them so happy to meet me
and saying their prayers and giving
their support each and every moment is
just so beautiful and every moment is
then more beautiful than the other one
so I am just I'm really enjoying it and
of course it's the first time we've been
back since the attack
are you scared at all being here if I
was scared I would not have been here
and so why now
why come back now I I tried my best to
come before as well but I was getting
out doing my a-levels and my GCSEs as
well and I was studying and and I think
this was this was just the best time I
also it is my Easter holidays of why
Easter break and and and I think this
was the right time the government also
provided support the Pakistan Army
provided support and security so all
these things combined together it just
worked this time and I hope that this is
not the this is the first time but it's
not the last time and I hope to be
coming again inshallah and this is my
home like I I can come anytime if I want
to and how important is it for you to
get out of Islamabad and go to the Swat
Valley for example I wish I can I can
visit all parts of Pakistan from Karachi
to the north
Hansa to melodious time to send and like
I I want to see my home as well but
inshallah next in the in the coming
trips I will be able to see more parts
of Pakistan but but just feeling this
coming to somebody is still great time
for me now you've obviously got a huge
number of supporters all across the
world and here but some people in
Pakistan seem quite frankly speaking if
you forgive me to hate you I mean I was
looking on your timeline on Twitter and
just seeing some of the comments that
the abuse that you get you know people
saying that you know you're at a Western
agent basically or that you should leave
Pakistan how does it feel when you when
you read those kind of comments firstly
I just don't understand like who why do
they oppose me and what is the reason
behind it I think if it's just against a
person hatred for no reason I just I
just don't know how to defend myself and
the only thing outside that I I love
Pakistan and I have an N I am Pakistani
and I want a better future for this
country that's why I started speaking
out for girls education that's why I did
not feel anything and I said even if the
terrorists attack me it does not matter
I will continue speaking out and it did
happen and I continued my my campaign
for girls education so my focus is only
working for the good I do not even look
at these comments so I don't know maybe
they hope that out see but I don't see
and I and I don't watch any anything
that's made on me any programs or any
any trolls or things and so but I hope
they try to understand what I stand for
but it must be upsetting after
everything that you've been through and
everything that you're trying to do to
have people here in your home country
more so than anywhere else have this
abuse at you I mean I was looking at I
don't if you've seen it but there's this
bizarre video of an anti Malala day
that's being held by children in the
school well I haven't seen these I have
not seen these and I think the most his
children would not know who Malala is
and what she stood for and they would
not know what I am NOT Malala means or
what I am Malala means and I think we
should allow children to learn about
these things themselves
and but also I want to say that this is
not the whole Palestine this does not
reflect that image of Pakistan it is
completely wrong I think we should not
just make conclusion by looking at what
is there on social media what do we see
on on media in TVs it's 200 million
people and I know that 99 percent more
than 99 percent stand with me support me
they believe in education they believe
in their daughters and I know so many
parents who have sent their daughters to
school because they heard my story I
have there's so many parents who named
their daughters after me because they
believe in their daughters and and I and
I think there is a change coming so in
anyone who wants who is against me wants
to say something should just come and
talk to me in the long term would you
like to come back here and live back in
Pakistan after university this is my
home and inshallah when I finish my
University which is PPE degree three
years so I will come back and and
meanwhile I want to visit Pakistan again
and see more parts of Pakistan visit
schools meet these young and amazing
girls who are standing up for their
rights in Pakistan I am just so happy
that we have this younger generation who
believe in change and they want to make
Pakistan a better country where everyone
has right to quality education where the
economy grows where we see equality for
everyone where we see equality for women
especially so seeing that gives me hope
and and I and I and I know that through
working together we can ensure that all
children in Pakistan can get quality
education and that women are empowered
and you've been asked this question so
many times but could you envisage a
future for yourself in politics here in
Pakistan so when I was 11 or 12 and when
there was extremism happening in Swat
Valley at that time I thought that by
becoming Prime Minister I can solve
every problem and I will eradicate all
these extremists and everything will be
fixed but I think now I have met many
leaders and politicians and Prime
Minister's and it seems that it's not
that simple and it's and I think my
focus right now is continuing my work
through Malala fund in making sure we
dish out to as many girls as we can
and their 130 million girls who cannot
go to school right now to ensure that
they can get quality education I have no
intention right now of politics and one
final question do you think there's
obviously been progress made in security
in Pakistan do you think there's been
enough of a change in the attitudes that
many people have towards women the idea
that men should be able to control women
and dictate whether they go to school or
how they dress we saw for example that
the killing of can deal below it's just
a few years ago for expressing herself
online has that changed enough do you
think I think it is changing it
definitely is changing positively and
women are stepping forward so I think
when women come out and they say that
women can be Pilate or they can be
engineers so they can be model so they
can be singers and I think when you see
these role models they inspire more and
more women to come out and and follow
their dreams as well and believe that
they can also do that things like
including the the Prime Minister of
Pakistan - it Bhutto she was first
female Prime Minister not just in
Pakistan but also in the whole Muslim
countries so seeing these role models
give you they they give you a hope that
you can do it - so there's there's that
reason but also more and more men are
accepting women as equal and but any
quality for men is not just a Pakistani
issue it's a global issue and right now
you see women are standing up
